awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: PAGE: Halau Ola Honua "Our living world, living laboratory"
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the outreach, research, and STEM instructional capacity at these institutions expands the opportunities for students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be locally relevant, and encourages a faculty community to look beyond the traditional classroom for intellectual and professional growth. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will serve as a model for novel pathways to careers in the geosciences for students underrepresented in that field.

The Partnerships in Geoscience Education (PAGE) collaborative among these Hawaii community colleges and the University of Hawaii Department of Oceanography will implement a strategic approach to increasing the number and success of Native Hawaiians majoring in the geosciences that will include outreach to local high schools, the implementation of a summer bridge that will increase mathematics readiness through calculus, the infusion of Native Hawaiian traditional knowledge into an expanded geoscience curriculum at the participating institutions, locally and culturally relevant research opportunities for undergraduates, community outreach to share the results of that research, and the engagement of environmental science specialists at each participating institution to ensure the greatest likelihood of students? academic success.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Hawaii Honolulu Community College

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Halau Ola Honua: Our Living World Our Living Laboratory Partnerships for Geoscience Education grant was a multicampus award that provided support for students to pursue geoscience research activities which incorporated native Hawaiian culture. These included work at sites such as fishponds, agricultural plots, public parks, mountain-top protected areas, and Hawaiian Homelands. At Honolulu Community College Chancellor Dr. Karen Lee served as the Principal Investigator, Associate Professor of Geography and Environment Dr. John DeLay was the Co-Principal Investigator, and Assistant Professor of Oceanography Dr. Michelle Nathan was the Environmental Science Specialist.

At Honolulu Community College, 18 native Hawaiian students received stipend support while enrolled in an undergraduate research experience course and pursuing geoscience projects indigenous perspectives. The projects included water quality studies in an island fishpond under Hawaiian stewardship of the Mokauea Fishermans' Association and water quality studies in a spring being used by Honolulu Community College Assistant Professor of Automotive Technology Robert Silva Jr.to cultivate the traditional Hawaiian staple crop called kalo. Related to the water quality studies and in collaboration with Dr. Nathan, Dr. Gabriel Peckham (Instructor Anatomy and Physiology) mentored a student who worked on linking antibodies to magnetic beads mixed with E. coli samples. The water balance of kalo was also investigated at the campus mala, a traditional dryland Hawaiian agricultural plot established by Honolulu Community College Assistant Professor of Hawaiian Studies Alapaki Luke. Students also were involved in mountain research exploring environmental characteristics such as temperature changes with elevation, endangered species relocation and fog occurrence on the slopes of the highest mountains on the islands of Oʻahu and Maui in collaboration with Drs. Wendy Kuntz Professor of Biology and Ecology at Kapiʻolani Community College and James Juvik Professor Emeritus of Geography and Environment at the University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo.

Students presented the results of their research at a variety of venues including community groups such as the Mokauea Fishermans' Association and national organizations such as the Society for the Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science National Diversity in STEM Conference. Students were also co-authors on presentations at local and national conferences with conservation and geoscience themes including the Hawaiʻi Conservation Conference and the American Geophysical Union.

Honolulu Community College grant faculty Drs. Nathan and DeLay began offering an OCN 102 Introduction to Environment and Sustainability course as part of the grant objective to create new introductory environmental science course taught throughout the University of Hawaii System. The new course is now regularly taught at the campus with a biological focus in addition to the existing GEO 101 Introduction to the Natural Environment course which has a physical focus. Students were recruited from the courses to participate in research projects and the new course is also now taught by grant faculty at local high schools in addition to the other campuses participating in the grant.

Dr. DeLay also helped to run geology field courses on the islands of Hawaiʻi, Maui, and Kauaʻi which were officially offered through grant faculty, Dr. Floyd McCoy Professor of Geology at Windward Community College which collaborated on the grant. Grant faculty with expertise took the students to a variety of geological features for on-site lectures and activities. A number of these sites also had important cultural associations which were also discussed. On Hawaiʻi, field trip sites included Hawaiʻi Volcanoes National Park, the Pacific Tsunami Museum, Kaumana Caves State Park, Lava Tree State Monument, the summit of Mauna Kea and a prehistoric quarry site in Puʻu Waʻawaʻa Forest Reserve. On Maui field trip sites included Haleakala National Park, ʻĀhihi Kīnaʻu Natural Area Reserve, Olowalu Petroglyphs, and Kaʻelekū Cavern. On Kauaʻi field trip sites included Kōkeʻe State Park, Hāʻena State Park, Makauwahi Cave Reserve, Hanapēpē Salt Flats.


Last Modified: 01/29/2023
Modified by: John Delay

Images (1 of )
  • Students and faculty participating in the Kauai geology field course visit Waimea Canyon and explore its origin.
    John DeLay
    Copyrighted
    John Delay
    Kauai Geology Field Course Waimea Canyon
  • Student Lono Mance explains his work using the campus meteorological station to determine the water balance of a traditional Hawaiian agricultural plot to judges at the Society for Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans National Diversity in STEM Conference.
    John DeLay
    Copyrighted
    John Delay
    Lono Mance SACNAS Poster Judges
  • Students visited the Kau Desert area of Kilauea volcano where, in 1790 a pyroclastic eruption of Kilauea created a column of ash the was deposited downwind during rainfall and captured the footprints of Hawaiians passing through the area.
    John DeLay
    John Delay
    1790 Pyroclastic Ash Hawaiian Footprint
  • Student Kiha Rodrigues pursued an existing interest in fog and the water balance of the Waianae Mountains by identifying fog frequency from trail camera pictures at the summit of Mount Kaala and was a co-author on an ecohydrology poster at the Fall Meeting of the American Geophysical Union.
    John DeLay
    Copyrighted
    John Delay
    Student Kiha Rodrigues Mount Kaala Cloud Forest
  • Students Kamalani Fukumitsu, Dani Aylett, Joel Nicolow, and Kamuela Gregoire (not pictured) deployed a meteorological station to evaluate the potential to catch fog as a water resource for Hawaiian Homelands residents at Kahikinui, Maui where a fogbow can be seen in the background.
    John DeLay
    Copyrighted
    John Delay
    Students Kahikinui Meteorological Station
  • Students Lei Kalaiwaa and Joel Nicolow stand on either side of a station they deployed to monitor temperature, relative humidity and fog presence using sensors and a camera at the summit of the highest mountain on Oahu. They were co-authors on a Hawaii Conservation Conference Presentation.
    John DeLay
    Copyrighted
    John Delay
    Students Lei Kalaiwaa Joel Nicolow 1200 Station
